questions.question: Question 1: Most congenital heart diseases arise between what weeks of embryogenesis?
questions.explanation:
Most congenital heart diseases arise from faulty embryogenesis during gestational weeks 3 to 
8 when major cardiovascular structures form and begin to function. The most common congenital heart disease is ventricular septal defect (VSD), whereas the 2nd 
most common is atrial septal defect (ASD).

questions.question: Question 2: What congenital heart defect is associated with Char syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Char syndrome is associated with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The clinical presentation of this syndrome includes PDA with facial dysmorphism and abnormal 
fifth digits. The following images show the facial dysmorphism associated with Char syndrome. 745

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following cardiac defects is not associated with Down's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Coarctation of the aorta is a feature of Turner's syndrome, not Down's syndrome. Down's syndrome (trisomy 21) is the most common cause of congenital heart disease (CHD).

questions.question: Question 4: What is the most common type of atrial septal defect?
questions.explanation:
Secundum atrial septal defect (ASD) is the most common type of ASD. 746 
Sold by @itachibot ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum caused by incomplete tissue formation 
that allows communication of blood between the left and right atria. It results in a left-to-right shunt. Excess blood flow through the ASD and/or the pulmonary valve 
results in a murmur. They are generally well-tolerated and usually do not become symptomatic 
before the age of 30 years. ASDs are classified according to their location: • Secundum ASD (90%) - usually isolated defects, can be of any size, multiple or fenestrated • Primum anomalies (5%) - occur adjacent to the AV valves, often associated with AV valve defects 
and/or VSD • Sinus venosus defects (5%) - located near SVC entrance and can be associated with anomalous 
pulmonary venous return to the right atrium

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a feature of tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.explanation:
Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) is a feature of the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), not left 
ventricular hypertrophy. The four cardinal features of tetralogy of Fallot are as follows: • Ventricular septal defect (VSD) • Obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract (subpulmonary stenosis) • An aorta that overrides the VSD • Right ventricular hypertrophy It is the most common type of cyanotic congenital heart disease (CHD). The heart is typically 
enlarged and is classically boot-shaped due to marked right ventricular hypertrophy. 747 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 5-year-old child was brought to the OPD for evaluation of cognitive impairment. Parents 
report that the child is overly-friendly with strangers. On examination, elfin facies and 
hypotonia are noted. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia. Which of the following cardiac 
defects is associated with this syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The given features are suggestive of Williams (Williams–Beuren) syndrome. It is associated with 
supravalvular aortic stenosis. This condition is due to deletions on chromosome 7 which includes the gene for elastin. These 
mutations may cause supravalvular stenosis by disrupting elastin–smooth muscle cell interactions 
during aortic morphogenesis. There is thickening of ascending aortic wall and consequent luminal 
constriction. Other features of the syndrome include: • Elfin facies - wide mouth, chubby cheeks, long philtrum, small nose, and delicate chin (as shown 
in the image) 748 
Sold by @itachibot • Cognitive abnormalities • Intellectual disability (usually mild) • Personality changes - over-friendliness to strangers • Hypotonia • Connective tissue abnormalities • Endocrine abnormalities (hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, hypothyroidism, early puberty)

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is the most common cause of mitral stenosis?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of mitral stenosis is rheumatic heart disease. Mitral stenosis is the most 
common lesion in rheumatic heart disease. In rheumatic mitral stenosis, calcification and fibrous bridging across the valvular commissures 
create fish mouth or buttonhole stenosis. Rheumatic mitral stenosis is associated with loud S1. The most common causes of various valvular diseases are: • Aortic stenosis (AS) - calcification due to normal aging or congenitally bicuspid aortic valves • Aortic regurgitation (AR) - dilatation of the ascending aorta, often secondary to hypertension 
and/or aging • Mitral regurgitation (MR) - myxomatous degeneration (mitral valve prolapse)

questions.question:
Question 8: A 42-year-old man presented with chest pain and exertional dyspnea for the past 2 months. 
He has no history of cardiac disease. Examination revealed an ejection systolic murmur. 
Transesophageal echocardiography was done, which revealed an aortic valve with 2 743 
Sold by @itachibot functional cusps and a valve area of 0.8 sq. cm. Which of the following is false regarding this 
condition?

options.c: It is due to abnormal fusion of valve commissures
options.d: Midline of larger cusp is major site of calcification

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario and echo findings are suggestive of calcific aortic stenosis secondary 
to bicuspid aortic valve (2 functional cusps). It is due to incomplete separation of valve 
commissures during development, not abnormal fusion. 749 
Sold by @itachibot In a congenitally bicuspid aortic valve, the 2 functional cusps are usually of unequal size. The 
larger cusp has a midline raphe that results from incomplete commissural separation during 
development. The raphe is frequently a major site of calcific deposits. This condition is associated with mutations in the following areas: • Chromosomes 18q, 5q, and 13q • Chromosome 9q - loss-of-function mutations in NOTCH1 gene Late complications include: • Aortic stenosis or regurgitation • Infective endocarditis • Aortic dilation and/or dissection. • Predisposed to progressive calcification - Approximately 50% of cases of aortic stenosis in 
adults. Note: Acquired bicuspid valves result from abnormal fusion of valve commissures because of an 
acquired deformity (rheumatic valve disease). It produces a conjoined cusp that is generally twice 
the size of the nonconjoined cusp.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 45-year-old woman who came for a routine check-up was incidentally found to have a late 
systolic murmur with a mid-systolic click. Echocardiography revealed thickening and 
redundancy of mitral leaflets with bulging into the left atrium. Which of the following is not a 
feature of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features and echocardiography findings are suggestive of mitral valve prolapse (MVP) 
or Barlow syndrome. It is not associated with degenerative calcified deposits (seen in calcific 
valvular degeneration, not MVP). Barlow syndrome is more common in females. It may be an isolated condition or less commonly 
can be associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan's syndrome. In this condition, there is mitral annular dilatation with floppy mitral valve leaflets. They prolapse 
or balloon back into the left atrium during systole. The following pathological changes are seen: • Interchordal ballooning (hooding) of the mitral leaflets • Thick, rubbery, redundant leaflets • Thickened mural endocardium The main histologic change is marked thickening of the spongiosa layer with deposition of mucoid 
called myxomatous degeneration. Most individuals diagnosed with MVP are asymptomatic. On auscultation, a mid-systolic click, 
sometimes followed by a mid to late systolic murmur is heard. Chest pain mimicking angina and 
dyspnea occur rarely. The complications include: • Infective endocarditis • Mitral insufficiency • Stroke or other systemic infarcts 750 
Sold by @itachibot • Arrhythmias • Sudden cardiac death (rarely)

questions.question:
Question 10: A 48-year-old man presented with dull aching abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past 2 
months. On examination, his face and chest appeared flushed. In a 24-hour urine sample, 
5HIAA levels were elevated. CT scan of the abdomen revealed a mass in the terminal ileum. 
Cardiac involvement in this syndrome is characterized by all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of carcinoid syndrome. Mitral stenosis is not a feature of 
cardiac involvement in this condition. Carcinoid heart disease refers to the cardiac manifestations caused by the bioactive compounds 
released by carcinoid tumors. Classically, the endocardium and valves of the right heart are 
primarily affected. Findings in carcinoid heart syndrome: • Endocardial plaque-like thickening and fibrosis • Tricuspid insufficiency • Pulmonary stenosis • No valve destruction • Myocardium not involved The left side of the heart is less commonly affected because the pulmonary vascular bed degrades 
the mediators. However, left heart carcinoid lesions can occur in the setting of ASD or VSD, or in 
the case of primary pulmonary carcinoid tumors.

questions.question: Question 11: Which is the most commonly involved valve in carcinoid heart disease?
questions.explanation:
Carcinoid heart disease most commonly affects the tricuspid valve. It usually affects right heart structures. The most common features are tricuspid regurgitation and 
pulmonary stenosis. 751 
Sold by @itachibot Rheumatic Fever and Endocarditis
